Magnetic nano carboxymethyl cellulose-alginate/chitosan hydrogel beads as biodegradable devices for controlled drug delivery
Mohammad Karzar Jeddi, Mehrdad Mahkam ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Azarbaijan Shahid Madani University, P.O. Box 53714-161, Tabriz, Iran
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: mahkam@azaruniv.edu (M. Mahkam)
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijbiomac.2019.05.210 0141-8130/© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 January 2019 Received in revised form 27 May 2019 Accepted 28 May 2019 Available online 31 May 2019
For the first time, nano carboxymethyl cellulose (NCMC) was synthesized via cellulose nanocrystal carboxymethylation. This nanomaterial was magnetized and used in bilayer alginate-chitosan hydrogel beads formulation to develop eco-friendly, smart, and magnetic sensitive hydrogel beads for the controlled pHsensitive release of dexamethasone as amodel drug.Water-soluble nanocrystalline cellulose (NCMC) and bilayer hydrogel beads were characterized in terms of size, surface morphology, surface modification, crystallinity, drug loading content, and in vitro drug release profile using various technics. Furthermore, the swelling behavior of hydrogels was examined and reported in three buffer media. The NCMCs improved drug loading capacity and swelling properties and also regulated drug release behavior of hydrogels. The hydrogel beads swelling specification exhibited a higher index in phosphate buffer at pH 5.8 than at pH 1.2 and 7.4. Besides, in vitro release of beads revealed excellent pH-sensitive drug release profiles and prevented release in the gastrointestinal tract. The beads showed high pH sensitivity for dexamethasone drug in pH 5.8 in compared to other pHmedia. The obtained results could introduce hydrogel beads as a high potential drug delivery system.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogels are a 3-D network of natural or synthetic polymer and achievable in several physical forms with numerous usages [1]. Triggeringmechanisms in smart hydrogels included temperature, pH, electrical fields, external chemicals, light, and shear stresses lead these hydrogels to exact control of fundamental material properties, such as swelling, porosity, physical structure, andmodulus. [2]. Highwater uptake capacity in hydrogels, generally 70–99%, creates a resemblance to the body tissues and could grant biocompatibility and encapsulation potential of hydrophilic drugs [3]. Hydrogels fromnatural polymers are highly appealing for well-controlled drug delivery due to safe, non-toxic, decreased side-effects in comparison to conventional methods, highly water uptake capacity and a cross-linked polymer network [4,5]. Among the various classes of drug delivery systems, oral controlled drug delivery is one of the most notable for the development of novel medicines. This drug delivery method has different benefits such as the reduction in dosing frequency, elimination of adverse effects and toxicity caused by extreme dosage, desirable control of drug concentration, and cost-effective manufacturing [6–8]. Recently, biodegradable, biocompatible, and non-toxic hydrogels have been studied in numerous oral targeted drug delivery researches [9]. For example, Taghizadeh et al. [10] fabricated chitosan nanoparticles and beads through the
.
ionic gelation procedure. It was found that the betamethasone and tetracycline release degree at the pH of 4.8 is much larger than that at the pH of 7.4. In another study,Wei et al. [11] prepared a novel glutathioneresponsive polymer prodrug nanoparticle based on 6-mercaptopurine and the folate receptor on the surface of leukemia cells with the ability of active targeting for leukemia therapy. Hydrogels are classified based on physical appearance asmatrix, film, or beads depends on the applied polymerization technique in the preparation steps [12]. Beads have a well-ordered size and shape (which can improve the delivery of the spheres to the specific target site), the huge surface area allowing for sufficient therapeutic coatings, and the high capability for encapsulation of various drugs and biomaterials [13]. Multi-layered beads, as a new generation of hydrogels, have agreeable physical properties in compared to single-layered beads [14]. So, the coating of beads (layer-bylayer adsorption) is a usual method to provide a diffusion barrier to retard rapid drug release in well-controlled drug delivery systems. In this case, bead hydrogels obtained from polysaccharides such as alginate, chitosan, and cellulose highly recommended as carriers for drug delivery [15–17]. Alginate is a water-soluble, anionic and liner polysaccharide that is frequently extracted from brown alga and composes of two monomeric units: α-(1-4)-L-guluronic acid (G) and β-(1-4)-Dmannuronic acid (M). This polymer is chelated by divalent ions (Ca2+, Sr2+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Ba2+, etc.) to form beads [18,19]. Chitosan is another outstanding natural polysaccharide in beads preparation. Chitosan has been used as carriers in drug delivery, such as delivery of proteins and peptides, genes, small molecules, and combinational [20].
Nanocellulosic materials are classified into three broad groups, depending uponwhether the cellulose nanofibers produced by the bacterial origin, mechanical, or chemical procedures. These categories are explained as bacterial cellulose (BC), cellulose nanofibrils (CNF), and cellulose nanocrystals (CNC), respectively. The rationale for using nanocellulose is the high surface area-to-volume ratio of the material, quintessential physical and chemical properties, renewability, biocompatibility, biodegradability, and spectacular mechanical properties that may enable high levels of drug binding at the surface of nanocellulose [21]. Among nanocellulosic material, CNCs have the ultrahigh potential for use as a means of releasing and binding drugs and has been repeatedly referred in the scientific literature. Yan et al. [22] used high encapsulating performance of alginate hydrogel beads with the ideal emulsifying property of nanocrystalline bacterial cellulose to develop a new formulation with high loading capacity of hydrophobic drugs.

In another recently published study on CNC for drug release, Supramaniam et al. [23] produced magnetic CNC-alginate hydrogel beads from the assembly of alginate andmagnetic nanocellulose for ibuprofen drug delivery. The uses of magnetic nanoparticles as drug delivery vectors and as tools for hyperthermia/thermal ablation, target selectively, and detect are witnessed. As a promising technology to treat cancer, various products are already on the market [24,25]. Synthesiswater-soluble derivatives of CNCs are supreme importance to target applications in the field of drug delivery. In the mentioned works, CNCwas combined with water-soluble polymers with the aim of meeting the conditions to enhance the processability and dispersibility of the beads in aqueous buffers and the matrix of polymers. However, using water-soluble derivatives of CNCs can hardly be seen. Here, we introduce a novel magnetic spherical hydrogel for pHsensitive drug delivery in simulated gastric (pH 1.2), intestinal (pH 7.4), and cancer cells (pH 5.8) fluids. In this study, nano carboxymethyl cellulose (NCMC) were synthesized, magnetized by Fe3O4 nanoparticles, and applied in alginate spherical hydrogels formulation (Scheme 1a and b). Then, prepared beads were coated by chitosan layer due to its rigid crystalline structure and low solubility in water and biologic fluids (pH 7.4). Dexamethasone (model drug) was selected as an effective drug in the clinical treatment of acute and chronic ocular disorders, popliteal artery disease, inflammatory diseases such as asthma, meningitis, and rheumatoid arthritis [27–29]. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time NCMC were synthesized via CNC carboxymethylation with the help of monochloroacetic acid and grafted in the alginate/chitosan beads structure. The NCMC and bilayer hydrogel beads were characterized in terms of size, surface morphology, surface modification, crystallinity, drug loading content, and in vitro drug release profile using various technics. In vitro release of
beads revealed excellent pH-sensitive drug release profiles and prevented release in the gastrointestinal tract.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Cellulose (purity, 99.9%) was purchased from Linter Pak Co, Ltd., Iran. Sodium alginate, chitosan (deacetylation degree N90%) and hydrochloric acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Calcium chloride, monochloroacetic acid (MCA), ammonium hydroxide, iron (II) sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O) and iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) were obtained from Merck Co. Dexamethasone was purchased from Iran Hormone Pharmaceutical Co. (Tehran, Iran). All chemicals and reagents were analytical grade and used as received.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of cellulose nanocrystal (CNC)
sections.text:
The suspension was prepared by hydrochloric acid to catalyze the hydrolysis of cellulose as reported elsewhere [30]. Briefly, 5 g of cellulose was dispersed in 175 mL of 4 N HCl (35 mL/g of cellulose) at 80
°C for 275 min. The hydrolysis was stopped by adding 10-fold cold deionized water (4 °C). The acid excess was washed by repeated centrifugation until a turbid supernatant was obtained. As prepared CNC was then dialyzed against running water until a pH of 7 was attained. Eventually, the dialyzed CNC suspension was freeze-dried and stored at 5 °C for further testing.

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of nano carboxymethyl cellulose (NCMC)
sections.text:
CNC was converted to NCMC in two steps, alkalization and etherification of CNC under heterogeneous condition. In the first step (alkalization pretreatment), 2 g of CNC was added in 150 mL isopropanol and stirred vigorously, while 20 mL 17.5% (w/v) aqueous NaOHwas added dropwise during 60 min at 10 °C. Stirring was continued for 2 h and then etherification reaction was started by adding 3.5 g of MCA in the reaction mixture. The reaction was heated up to the temperature of 70 °C and stirred for 4 h. Themixture was filtrated, added in 200mL of aqueous methanol and neutralized (pH 6–8) with acetic acid then filtered again. The product waswashed three times with 80% (v/v) aqueous ethanol and dried at 40 °C in an oven for 24 h. The degree of substitution (DS) was explored 0.7 by conductometric titration following the previously published protocol [31] for CNCs.

sections.heading: 2.5. Synthesis of magnetic nano carboxymethyl cellulose (MNCMC)
sections.text:
At the first, 1 g NCMC was dissolved in 80 mL deionized water. The solution was added to a three-necked flask and purged with N2 gas at 75 °C with constant stirring. After 30 min, FeCl3·6H2O (1.296 g), FeSO4·7H2O (1.112 g) were added to the solution. As the mixture was heated 75 °C, pH of the solution adjusted to 9–10 using ammonia solution. The solution color became dark after addition of ammonia. The reaction was refluxed for 60 min and then cooled to room temperature. MNCMC (the dark brown precipitate) was washed three times with
distilled water and ethanol to remove the unreacted reagents and separated using a permanent magnet.

2.7. Preparation of chitosan-coated MNCMC-alginate beads
sections.text:
The preparation process of the hydrogels is shown in Scheme 1b. Briefly, 2% (w/v) solution of chitosan was prepared by dissolving of chitosan in acetic acid aqueous solution (pH 5). The wet microcapsules obtained from the previous step were transferred into the mentioned solution and stirred for 30 min. Finally, coated beads were filtered and washed with copious amount of deionized water to remove impurities. The beads were dried at room temperature for 72 h and named B1, B2, B3, B4, and B5 based on MNCMC consistency in beads formulation (Table 1).
2.8. Encapsulation efficiency and drug loading
A direct method was used to determine DEX content in the spheres. Briefly, 0.01 g of the hydrogels were accurately weighed and then crushed (for complete drug extraction). The crushed beads were removed into the PBS (phosphate buffer solution, 0.01 M, pH 7.4) and stirred for a day at room temperature. The syringe nano filter was used for filtration of the solution. The drug concentration was determined spectrophotometrically at the absorption maximum (λmax) of DEX using a 1 cm quartz cell. The drug loading (DL%) of beads and the encapsulation efficiency (EE%) were estimated by using Eqs. (1) and (2) respectively.

hydrogels were weighed and immersed in 20mL of the prepared buffer solutions at room temperature; at specific time intervals, the swollen beads were separated carefully from the buffer solution and the water adsorbed on the surface of the beads were blotted with a filter paper and weighed immediately. sections.heading: 2.10. Drug release studies
sections.text:
In vitro drug release was carried out like our previous work [32]. The dried beads (20 mg) were dispersed in 2 mL buffer solution and transferred into a dialysis bag. Eventually, the bag was closed and removed into a beaker containing 25 mL of the same aqueous buffer solutions maintained at 37 ± 1 °C. The outer solution was continuously stirred during the release study. Every 1 h, 3 mL of the solutionwaswithdrawn and analyzed spectrophotometrically (λmax=239 nm). Thewithdrawn solution was replaced with the same volume of fresh buffer solution to keep the total volumes constant. sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of CNC, NCMC, and MNCMC
sections.text:
FTIR spectra of CNC, NCMC, andMNCMC, are shown in Fig. 6a. The cellulose nanocrystals (CNC) stretching vibration in O\\H and C\\H groups are appeared in 3419 cm−1 and 2902 cm−1. The peaks at 1160 and 1070 cm−1 are attributed to the saccharide structure. The bending vibration for –CH2 in C6 are seen in 1431 cm−1 and the peak in 1058 cm−1 is related to C\\O stretching vibration [33,34]. In NCMC IR spectra, a strong peak appeared in 1610 cm−1 thatmake it different fromCNC. It can be related to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the carbonyl groups in
fied (f) and modified (g) surface of MNCM-alginate bead with chitosan layer.

In MNCMC, a new peak was emerged in 568 cm−1 that pertained to Fe\\O band in Fe3O4 nanoparticles, indicating successfully synthesize of Fe3O4 on the surfaces of NCMC [35]. According to the TEM images (Fig. 1), all the cellulosic nanoparticles (CNC, NCMC, and MNCMC) were exhibited rod-like nanocrystals. The widths of the CNCs derivatives were b50 nm and with the lengths being around 50–350 nm (Fig. 1a and b). This size distribution is in line with the most earlier studies [36,37]. It seems that nanocrystals agglomeration in NCMC and MNCMC have been increased in compared to CNC (Fig. 1d–f) thatmay be the result of surfacemodification of crystals by hydrophilic groups. Besides, Fig. 1f shows thatmagnetic nanoparticles have precipitated on the surface of NCMC orderly. AFM images shown the rod-like cellulose nanocrystals (widths b50 nm and lengths between 150 and 200 nm). During hydrolysis of cellulose, noncrystalline parts were sequestered, and aggregate crystals obtained (Fig. 1c). Accumulation in the nanocellulose solutions usually occurs and is observed in CNC surface morphology study images most probably due to nano-rods superimposition during drying [38]. Fig. 2a shows X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern characteristic peaks of the CNC, NCMC, and
MNCMC. XRD pattern of CNC displayed four peaks at 2θ = 15°, 16.5°, 22.6° and 34.3° which corresponds to the typical reflection planes of type I cellulose [1–10], [110], [012] and [004] respectively that similarly published recently [39]. The distinctive peaks of NCMC and CNC have not anymajor difference that can be exhibited preservation of the crystalline form of nanocellulose during carboxymethylation. Eventually, XRD patterns of MNCMC with obvious peaks were shown and related diffraction patterns in 2θ = 30.41°, 35.62°, 43.31°, 53.52°, 57.16°, and 62.92° comport to the (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) reflections, respectively [40]. Besides, successful carboxymethylation of cellulose nanocrystalswas shown in 13CNMRspectra of nano carboxymethyl cellulose (Fig. 2b). The peaks in 13C NMR spectra are related to different carbons in AGU groups. The weak peak in 179.521 ppm is attributed to the carbonyl groups at C6 of glucose units.

Magnetic beads moved toward the external magnetic field which could be indicated successful magnetization of beads (Fig. 4b and c). Also, Fig. 4d and e exhibit prepared beads in aqueous media with regular size and shape after control of conditions.
The SEM images of beads are shown in Fig. 5. The shape of the beads was completely spherical without severe cracks. However, they deformed during the drying process. This deformation is inevitable and can be related to the high volume of water inside the hydrogels [42,43]. Generally, increasingMNCMC ratio in beads formulation caused to amplify the cracks quantity, but these cracks did not have a significant effect on their shape and performance (Fig. 5a–e). Although both the MNCMC-alginate and MNCMC-alginate/chitosan beads have harsh and folds surface (see. Fig. 5f and g), the differences still exist among them. The SEM image in Fig. 5g shows that the dents are deeper on the surface of MNCMC-alginate/chitosan. The difference could be attributed to the existence of chitosan coating on the surface of MNCMC-alginate hydrogels.
In the IR spectrum of alginate (Fig. 6a), the bands at 1622, 1423 cm−1 were attributed to peaks of carbonyl groups (asymmetric and symmetric stretching respectively) and absorption in 1022 cm−1 caused by C-O-C stretching vibration. Pure chitosan IRpeaks (Fig. 6a) indicated a wide band in the 3424 cm−1 (O\\H and N\\H stretching vibrations), a weak absorb at 2922 cm−1 (C\\H stretching) and a medium peak at 1625 cm−1 (carbonyl stretching). There were two peaks in 1261 and 1545 cm−1 regions that shown ether stretching and N\\H bending vibrations respectively [44,45].
The beads IR peaks resembled each other with many overlapped peaks (Fig. 6b). However, some clear distinguished peaks confirmed layer-by-layer beads formation. That corroborated the absence of new covalent bonds in the prepared beads. That was predicted due to multi-interactions (hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interactions) especially “coulomb forces” between the polymers [16]. Broadband in 3424 cm−1 (Fig. 6 A and C) moved to a higher frequency in 3444 cm−1 (Fig. 6 B and D) due to interactions between O\\H groups in alginate and MNCMC with N\\H groups in chitosan. A new peak appeared in chitosan coated beads in 1735 cm−1 that did not exist in uncoated ones. Also, a peak in 560 cm−1 (Fig. 6 C and D) might be related to themagnetic nanoparticles (MNCMC) in hydrogel's formulation [23].
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to determine the thermal behavior of beads and results shown in Fig. 7. The temperature range tested was from 50 °C to 750 °C. The diagram across all bead's samples were similar, ending at roughly all of the original weight after reaching 700 °C. TGA graphs of as prepared beads were presented mass loss in the four stages. In the first stages, the hydrogels mass was decreased approximately 13% between 30 and 150 °C, due to the capsulated water evaporation in the beads and degradation of CaCO3. All but 17% of the polymers mass were reduced between 200 and 300 °C in the second stage, that caused by breaking and losing of O\\H groups on the alginate structure. The third mass loss of around 29% between 270 °C and 450 °C was attributed to the thermal decomposition and deacetylation of chitosan structure. A major fraction of organic species in the beads were completely decomposed above 600 °C but the Fe3O4 on the MNCMC remained [46,47]. Despite the impression that lower concentrations of alginate aremore thermally stable, it is possible to observe the limitation of this interpretation by the weight loss in TGA diagram. It is probably due to the higher intermolecular interaction between chains, which leads to a more cohesive system. The addition of iron nanoparticles (MNCMC) to hydrogels showed there was higher water content for the alginate with iron particles than when it was pure; directly proportional to the iron concentration [48].

sections.heading: 3.3. Swelling properties and in vitro drug release studies
sections.text:
Swelling is a notable property in the hydrogels for drug delivery applications and usually related to the drug release. So, pH effects on the
hydrogels swelling behavior of beads were investigated in pH 1.2, pH 5.8 and pH 7.4 media (Fig. 8a–c). All the beads swelled quickly in pH 5.8 and the rate of swelling was ultra-high (22–119 wt%). However, the swelling rate in pH 1.2 and 7.4 was 16–27 wt% and 17–68 wt% respectively. It means that the beads were exceedingly sensitive to pH variations. Probably, the presence of hydrophilic groups on the alginate, chitosan, and MNCMC structures resulted in swelling, so a high amount of water was reserved inside the beads. Under acidic condition (pH = 1.2), the functional groups such as carboxyl groups in alginate and MNCMC protonated. This factor resulted to increase hydrogen bond force between alginate and MNCMC from one side and chitosan from another side. However, in stronger alkaline conditions, these groups, loosed their protons and due to the electrostatic repulsion, the bonds between them became weaker and at last, enhances the hydrogels swelling by penetration of water molecules into the beads. The swelling ratio decreased in pH 7.4, which may be ascribed to the cracking of the beads due to the reaction of phosphate and calcium ions in the basic media [49]. Despite high swelling, the shape of beads did not deform that may be related to the second layer of chitosan. As a conclusion, the electrostatic repulsion within the tested beads made the hydrogel dramatically swell.
The potential of the hydrogel beads in pH-sensitive drug delivery systems was studied and the results reported in Fig. 8d–f. According to the release graphs, there was a direct relationship between the increase in drug release and encapsulation efficiency and in all buffers, the maximumdrug release belonged to B2 beads. The releaseddrug in pH 1.2 did not surpass 29.5% of encapsulated dexamethasone. It can be related to low solvability of dexamethasone in this pH and stable form of alginate beads in acidic conditions. Almost 90% of the encapsulated drugwas released in pH 5.8. However, the released rate dropped again in basic media (pH 7.4) significantly (26.19%). The excess percentage of the release of hydrogels in pH 5.8 in compared to 7.4, probably related to the stronger hydrogen bond in the alkaline media and also the low solubility of chitosan in basic media. High potential drug loading capacity, release performance, and biocompatibility ofMNCMC-alginate/chitosan hydrogel beads may result to a broad range of applications in pharmaceutics, where they are used as drug delivery systems for encapsulation and controlled release of drugs.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In conclusion, nano carboxymethyl cellulose (NCMC) was synthesized through carboxymethylation of CNC, incorporated into alginatebased beads formulation, and applied as a carrier for dexamethasone delivery. The beads showed high pH sensitivity for dexamethasone drug in pH 5.8 in compared to other pH media. The optimum formulation of beads was obtained where the amount MNCMC was 2% of bead weight (B2). The presence of MNCMC in spherical hydrogels formulation improved the swelling degree, drug loading capacity, and drug release behavior. Economical raw materials, simple, and green manufacturing procedure make these hydrogels highly promising carrier for drug delivery applications.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 19 January 2019 Received in revised form 27 May 2019 Accepted 28 May 2019 Available online 31 May 2019 For the first time, nano carboxymethyl cellulose (NCMC) was synthesized via cellulose nanocrystal carboxymethylation. This nanomaterial was magnetized and used in bilayer alginate-chitosan hydrogel beads formulation to develop eco-friendly, smart, and magnetic sensitive hydrogel beads for the controlled pHsensitive release of dexamethasone as amodel drug.Water-soluble nanocrystalline cellulose (NCMC) and bilayer hydrogel beads were characterized in terms of size, surface morphology, surface modification, crystallinity, drug loading content, and in vitro drug release profile using various technics. Furthermore, the swelling behavior of hydrogels was examined and reported in three buffer media. The NCMCs improved drug loading capacity and swelling properties and also regulated drug release behavior of hydrogels. The hydrogel beads swelling specification exhibited a higher index in phosphate buffer at pH 5.8 than at pH 1.2 and 7.4. Besides, in vitro release of beads revealed excellent pH-sensitive drug release profiles and prevented release in the gastrointestinal tract. The beads showed high pH sensitivity for dexamethasone drug in pH 5.8 in compared to other pHmedia. The obtained results could introduce hydrogel beads as a high potential drug delivery system. © 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
